page.title: 03LANDSCAPE DYMCHURCH SEA WALL
page.content: When we were at the top of the sea wall everyone had the urge to run down to the beach. The wind was blowing and the sea wall was slippery and slimy so people were sliding over. The concrete was cold to sit on. Barnacles and mussels were clinging on to the groynes and breakers. In parts where the wall was decaying, little pools of water made homes for stranded crabs and starfish. Ladybirds which live higher up in the wall were crawling into the tiniest little nooks and crannies they could find. The sea was greeny blue colour and at the horizon the sky matched it. The view on the road was very clear but when a lorry came dust flew up and settled on the wall. We looked past the road to the green fields and the hazy hills beyond.
